title: Carlos Restrepo (manager)
text:
Carlos Alberto "Piscis" Restrepo Isaza (born 5 March 1961) is a <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach.
Never having the opportunity of playing the sport professionally because of an injury, he began his coaching career at his early 20s. After some time spent managing in minor leagues and regional teams in his home country, he took over several <a href="FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup">U-17</a> and <a href="FIFA%20U-20%20World%20Cup">U-20</a> <a href="Colombia%20national%20football%20team">Colombia national football team</a>s. He then began coaching teams such as <a href="Once%20Caldas">Once Caldas</a>, <a href="Independiente%20Medell%C3%ADn">Independiente Medellín</a>, <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Junior">Atlético Junior</a>, <a href="Deportes%20Quind%C3%ADo">Deportes Quindío</a> and <a href="Deportes%20Tolima">Deportes Tolima</a>. He won the first division tournament of <a href="F%C3%BAtbol%20Profesional%20Colombiano">Fútbol Profesional Colombiano</a> in 1995 with <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Junior">Atlético Junior</a>.
He then went on to manage <a href="Deportivo%20T%C3%A1chira">Deportivo Táchira</a> of the <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Venezolana">Primera División Venezolana</a>, or Venezuelan Professional Football League. He arrived to <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a> in 2002, and coached <a href="Municipal%20P%C3%A9rez%20Zeled%C3%B3n">Municipal Pérez Zeledón</a> for three years, where he won the Apertura Championship of <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica's first division</a> in 2004, against all odds. In 2005, he was signed by <a href="Brujas%20F.C.">Brujas</a> where he was able to build a very competitive team and battled to win the <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica's first division</a> title.
In 2013, he managed <a href="Colombia%20U-20">Colombia U-20</a> team to win their third <a href="South%20American%20Youth%20Championship">South American Youth Championship</a>.
In 2017, he was named coach for <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20Olimpia">Olimpia</a> after <a href="Hector%20Vargas">Hector Vargas</a> was fired.
In 2019, he was named coach for <a href="Real%20C.D.%20Espa%C3%B1a">Real España</a>. After that, in 2020 he was named coach of <a href="AD%20San%20Carlos">AD San Carlos</a> in Costa Rican first division.
Managerial statistics.
"Statistics accurate as of 12 June 2017"
